#USA -Prices for #diesel, have surged 76.5% in the last year to hit a record $5.56 per gallon. Inventories for the most commonly used diesel have dropped 43% since 2020 to the lowest since 2014. @IFAmedia @lidl_ireland @McConalogue @martinheydonfg There's something rotten in the state of food production and distribution. Why are we even on this race to the bottom? 

EU pours billions into farming subsidies so that supermarkets can sell low price food? Makes no sense. Keep EU food prices up and add tariffs for imports.

I don’t see it happening to scale. You only have to look at the fruit farming debacle to see the cost effective labour is not available on mainland to maintain low prices.

@GTCost @eosfuturedesign For yrs Ohio's Lake Eerie was in crisis. Fertiliser & slurry pollution was so bad the toxic algae it nourished cud be seen from space. An emergency "bill of rights” granted lake legal personhood & "right to exist, flourish & naturally evolve”

Should we too make #ecocide a crime?

Seeing a good bit of this in fields where I wouldn’t normally.  Is it an indication of reduced land fertility due to reduction in chemical fertiliser compound use??? https://t.co/1oQLCYjdgx
By following the cows with fertiliser rather than blanket spreading, farmers can avoid luxury uptake of nitrogen https://t.co/cwOIqh0H9o
Take home messages from this study - fertiliser application has a much larger effect than inhibitors on soil microbial communities. With @AoifeDuff2 @ForrestalPJ @IsraelIkoyi

NBPT on soil bacterial and fungal composition or abundance. Functioning of the microbiome was mainly unaffected by inhibitors. Adding fertiliser and the type of fertiliser (CAN or Urea) affected the fungal but not the bacterial community structure.

@inkdanarchist @EgoAndIts0wn @CtrlPew @CrackedJacket I assumed the further north the more luck I'd have but I still live in an area where fellas have been raided for having a bit too much fertiliser, shall we say.

“I thought I would not live to see the day when bags of fertiliser would cost €50-€55. The price continues to go up.”

https://t.co/73dUzkZYQr

@RShrubb Basic crops have become ridiculously expensive to grow, MGO increased 70% in 3 months, fertiliser has increased 350% in 4 months so far, Hollands growers who forward buy gas and electricity for their tunnels have sold their energy back and are not growing. Hungry days coming

@BritFeather @LucieCatnip @bharris1968 I test pharma products (for heavy metals) and man, anything involving nitric acid. It's used in so much, especially in fertiliser production (another shortage due to pandemic, supply chains snarls). Practically everything in metals testing needs nitric.

Our technical specialists and editorial team were delighted to spend the day on the @DiscoverCAFRE hill farm in Glenwherry, Antrim. Discussions focussed on measures being taken on the suckler and sheep unit and the steps taken to reduce carbon emissions from peatlands. https://t.co/rTO0E6Tnld

Passionate about what they do as farmers themselves and as part of our Producer Group, Michael and Tennyson spend many hours out on farms chatting with farmers to help them maximise the number of their Herefords that meet the qualifying criteria. #somuchtosavour https://t.co/t5UIOUfqdU
